titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Henry James Collection
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday January 4, 2019 at 04:11

did.unittitle: Henry James collection

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Henry James Collection is comprised of correspondence, writings, personal papers, and printed material by and about the American author Henry James. The majority of correspondence consists of letters sent from James to recipients, most notably his literary agent James B. Pinker, author William Edward Norris, and publishers. The collection also includes correspondence between James B. Pinker and James' nephew, Henry James, and sister-in-law, Alice Howe Gibbens James. Autograph manuscripts for "The Pension Beaurepas," The Europeans, and "New England: An Autumn Impression," can be found in the collection. Personal papers include a photograph of James with Mrs. Humphry Ward and a cancelled check received by James from Ticknor and Fields.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired from various sources. For more information see notes for each acquisition.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Henry James Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Henry James Collection. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing in 2014, including rehousing and minimal organization. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below, identified by a unique call number and titled according to month and year of acquisition.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
Former call numbers: Za James, Uncat ZA MS 24, Uncat ZA MS 262, and Za J233 +1.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Henry James Collection is comprised of correspondence, writings, personal papers, and printed material by and about the American author Henry James.

The majority of correspondence consists of outgoing letters sent from James to recipients, most notably his literary agent James B. Pinker, author William Edward Norris, and publishers. The collection also includes correspondence between James B. Pinker and James' nephew, Henry James, and sister-in-law, Alice Howe Gibbens James.

Autograph manuscripts and proofs provide insight into James' creative process. James' autograph manuscript, corrected, for "The Pension Beaurepas" can be found in the collection; the Beinecke Library acquired pages 1-13 in 1951 and pages 14-169 in 1982. Pages 1-13 of "The Pension Beaurepas" were bound with an autograph manuscript of The Europeans before they arrived at the Beinecke Library and they have not been separated. James' work on "New England: An Autumn Impression" can be traced from autograph manuscript drafts and corrected galley proofs to the final printed version. Printed material includes the published versions of James' writings, including "New England: An Autumn Impression," as well as scholarship about James.
Personal papers include a photograph of James with Mrs. Humphry Ward and a cancelled check received by James from Ticknor and Fields.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four groupings: 1910-1959 Acquisitions, 1982 Acquisition, 1992 Acquisition, and Printed Material.

did.unittitle: 1910-1959 Acquisitions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence and writings. Correspondence is largely comprised of James' outgoing letters, most notably to James B. Pinker, William Edward Norris, and incoming letters from publishers. Letters between James' relatives and James B. Pinker can also be found in the Correspondence series. The Writings series includes autograph manuscripts, typescripts, and proofs, which provide insight into James' creative process, particularly at the end of his career. The first thirteen pages of James' "The Pension Beaurepas," which have been bound with The Europeans , is located in the Writings series. The remaining pages of "The Pension Beaurepas" can be found in the 1982 Acquisition.
Former call number: Za James.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired by gift and purchase, 1910-1959. For more information see catalog cards filed in the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: I. Correspondence, 1867-1934. II. Writings, 1896-1914.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Richard L. Purdy (Yale, 1925), 1982 and purchased from John Howell on the Chauncey Brewster Tinker Prize Fund, John Ewing Durand Memorial Fund, Eugene G. O'Neill Memorial Fund, and Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 1982.

1992 Acquisition

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: I. Correspondence, 1898-1914. II. Personal Papers, 1867.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence and personal papers of Henry James. The correspondence is largely comprised of James' outgoing correspondence, with a few exceptions, such as a postcard sent to James from Edith Wharton. The acquisition also includes a photograph of James and Mrs. Humphry Ward and a cancelled check.
Former call number: Uncat ZA MS 262.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mrs. Donald G. Wing, 1992.
